title: 111_hr4348
content: The Act may be cited as the "Telework Tax Incentive Act". The Congress finds that billions of dollars are spent annually on transportation needs, with congestion costing over $87 million in extra time and fuel in 2007. On-road vehicles contributed 31.9% of nitrogen oxide emissions in 2008. Teleworking could save 450 million barrels of oil, reduce greenhouse gases by 84 million tons, and cut highway maintenance costs by over $3 billion annually. The average American daily commute is 51 minutes. Teleworking has shown to increase employee productivity by 87 percent. 76 percent of private sector employers now provide technical support for remote workers, a 27 percent increase since 2007. 56 percent of Federal IT professionals indicated that their agencies support teleworkers. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR TELEWORKING. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a teleworking credit. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a teleworking credit allowing eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified teleworking expenses up to $1,000 per teleworker for a taxable year. The credit is reduced proportionally for individuals in teleworking arrangements for less than a full year. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a teleworking credit for eligible taxpayers who work under a teleworking arrangement. An eligible taxpayer is defined as an individual or employer involved in teleworking. A teleworking arrangement requires an employee to telework for an employer for at least 75 days per year. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a teleworking credit for eligible taxpayers who work under a teleworking arrangement. Qualified teleworking expenses include furnishings and electronic equipment used for teleworking. Telework is defined as performing work functions using electronic technologies to reduce or eliminate the commute to a traditional worksite. The credit allowable for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax amount. The new section introduces a teleworking credit for eligible taxpayers. Qualified expenses include furnishings and electronic equipment for teleworking. The credit is limited by the regular tax amount and any excess can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Special rules include basis reduction and recapture by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary can recapture the benefit of any credit for property no longer eligible. No credit for property used outside the US or if taxpayer elects not to apply. No double benefits allowed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow credits under specific sections. A new paragraph is added regarding credits allowed under section 30E. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts paid or incurred after the date of the enactment of this Act, in taxable years ending after such date.
